This course is made for students coming in from high school basically speaking French. Not for those coming in from L1 and L2 the year before. The jump from L2 to L3 is too excessive and this made the semester a nightmare

The "Course Packet" and daily homework model definitely resulted in a much steeper learning curve than language classes I took in high school, which was a key strength of the course. I also appreciated the biweekly evaluations, which gave me a continuous sense of what I had been learning and where I needed to improve. 
I would have liked more opportunity to explore the cultural and literary significance of the works we studied, although I understand that perhaps that is not feasible in an L3 language course.

I think the combination of reading a book, listening to French, speaking, and writing grammar every day really worked. I felt like every area was improving at the same time. I can't really think of any weaknesses.
The strengths are that we cover the French language holistically - in our reading, writing, and speaking. I can't think of any weaknesses.

I liked how small the classes are for French and the engagement is very personal with the teacher. I don't think that the course could be further improved given its small size and high professor involvement.

No, unless a requirement. No contemporary media and very little practical conversational practice. Get ready for generally boring books (aside from Camus's L'Etranger) and old media--Truffaut is cool to know about in cinema but Jules et Jim is not of great merit. The French Department generally needs more diversity and cultural competency in their pedagogy, and was as a better lens on the real world outside the classroom. The great opportunity of Yale French classes that meet five days a week with exceptionally dedicated, knowledgeable, and conscientious faculty within small classes of 15 or less is that it could truly be a fantastic collaborative and conversational space, engaging with literature as well as the present world, such as social issues in the Francophone world with relevant vocabulary. This opportunity is wasted on an outdated curriculum and rote memorization of generally not-so-helpful vocabulary. Grammar practice is generally good though, which is obviously important for learning French! But then again, you could do that with myriad apps/ software and save yourself some of the agony of this course. It is sad, considering the French faculty are fascinating and accomplished, that a more vibrant, productive, and engaging dialogue isn't created by this course.
